paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral mRNA vaccination induce an interferon-rich state that sensitizes tumors to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice receiving intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations, pooled across repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice receiving vaccine only, ICI only, or vehicle, pooled across matched controls.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
